00048 /*****************************************************************************\
00049  *      File:   md.c
00050  *
00051  *      Description: The interface to the internal representation of the
00052  *                   IMPACT Meta-Description Language
00053  *
00054  *      Creation Date:  March 1995
00055  *
00056  *      Authors: John C. Gyllenhaal and Wen-mei Hwu
00057  *
00058  *      Revisions:
00059  *           Shail Aditya (HP Labs)  February 1996
00060  *           Changed MD_get_xxx() arguments to be consistent with MD_set_xxx()
00061  *           Added MD_num_xxx() which returns number of sections, entries, etc.
00062  *
00063  *           John C. Gyllenhaal  May 1996
00064  *           Folded Shail's changes back into IMPACT's version
00065  *           Changed low-level representation to use hex for integers
00066  *           Added MD_rename_entry(), MD_delete_element(), MD_max_field_index()
00067  *                 MD_max_element_index, and MD_print_md_declarations()
00068  *           Changed all error messages to uniformly use MD_punt()
00069  *
00070  *           John C. Gyllenhaal July 1996
00071  *           Implemented Shail Aditya's suggestion of adding void pointers to
00072  *           MD_Section and MD_Entry for the user's use.  Added functions
00073  *           MD_set_section_ext(), MD_get_section_ext(), MD_set_entry_ext(), 
00074  *           and MD_get_entry_ext().
00075  *
00076  *           John C. Gyllenhaal January 1998
00077  *           Implemented Marie Conte's and Andy Trick's suggestion of adding
00078  *           a new data type 'BLOCK' to allow an user to specify a block
00079  *           of binary data the same way ints, doubles, strings, and links
00080  *           are specified in fields.  (User readable input/output 
00081  *           respresents this data as a hex string.  Note that this data type
00082  *           may not make sense to programs running on different platforms or
00083  *           compiled with different compilers!)
00084  *           Also, switched to internal version of strdup (MD_strdup) in order
00085  *           to handle 'out of memory' errors more gracefully.
00086  *
00087  *
00088  * *
00089 \*****************************************************************************/

00107  */
00108 typedef struct MD_Buf
00109 {

00111   int buf_size;
00112 }

00141  * Internal md library routines.

00145 /* Error routine, fmt and trailing args are the same as printf.  
00146  * Adds header message identifying error as coming from MD_library and
00147  * which md caused the error.
00148  * Exits with value 1.
00149  */
00150 static void
00151 MD_punt (MD * md, char *fmt, ...)
00152 {
00153   va_list args;
00154 
00155   /* Print error message header.
00156    * Allow NULL to be passed in for md 
00157    */
00158   fprintf (stderr, "\nMD library error");
00159   if (md == NULL)
00160     fprintf (stderr, ":\n");
00161   else
00162     fprintf (stderr, " (in \"%s\"):\n", md->name);
00163 
00164   /* Print out error message */
00165   va_start (args, fmt);
00166   vfprintf (stderr, fmt, args);
00167   va_end (args);
00168   fprintf (stderr, "\n");
00169 
00170   exit (1);
00171 }
00172 
00173 /* MD warning routine, args are the same as fprintf.  
00174  * Prints message to outand returns to caller.
00175  *
00176  * Provided as a useful place to place a breakpoint when debugging warnings.
00177  */
00178 static void
00179 MD_warn (FILE * out, char *fmt, ...)
00180 {
00181   va_list args;
00182 
00183   /* Make sure warning goes on new line */
00184   fprintf (out, "\n");
00185 
00186   /* Print out warning message */
00187   va_start (args, fmt);
00188   vfprintf (out, fmt, args);
00189   va_end (args);
00190 
00191   /* Automatically add newline to warning */
00192   fprintf (out, "\n");
00193 }
00194 
00195 /* Returns a pointer to a new string which is a duplicate of the
00196  * string to which 'string' points.  The space for the new string is 
00197  * obtained using the malloc() function.  If out of memory,
00198  * an error message using MD_punt will occur.  
00199  *
00200  * The library strdup() routine was originally used, but it 
00201  * didn't handle out of memory errors gracefully.  -JCG 1/15/98
00202  */
00203 static char *
00204 MD_strdup (char *string)
00205 {
00206   char *new_string;
00207   unsigned int len, i;
00208 
00209   /* Get length of string */
00210   len = 0;
00211   while (string[len] != 0)
00212     {
00213       len++;
00214     }
00215 
00216   /* Malloc buffer (len + 1) to hold string */
00217   if ((new_string = (char *) malloc (len + 1)) == NULL)
00218     MD_punt (NULL, "MD_strdup: Out of memory (string length %i).", len);
00219 
00220   /* Copy string to new_string, including terminator */
00221   for (i = 0; i <= len; i++)
00222     new_string[i] = string[i];
00223 
00224   /* Return new copy of string */
00225   return (new_string);
00226 }
00227 
00228 /* MD Symbol table code for md section, entry and field names.
00229  * Internal MD use only!  Not designed to be used by non-MD functions!
00230  */
00231 /* Malloc's a string buffer and concatinates the two strings into it.
00232  * This newly malloced bufffer is returned.
00233  * 
00234  * Used by MD to build descriptive names for symbol tables.
00235  */
00236 static char *
00237 MD_concat_strings (char *string1, char *string2)
00238 {
00239   char *buf;
00240   int len;
00241 
00242   /* The buffer length needed is the length of both strings plus 1 for
00243    * the terminator.
00244    */
00245   len = strlen (string1) + strlen (string2) + 1;
00246   if ((buf = (char *) malloc (len * sizeof (char))) == NULL)
00247     {
00248       MD_punt (NULL,
00249                "MD_concat_strings: Out of memory mallocing buffer (size %i)",
00250                len);
00251     }
00252 
00253   /* Concat strings */
00254   sprintf (buf, "%s%s", string1, string2);
00255 
00256   /* Return concatinated strings */
00257   return (buf);
00258 }
00259 
00260 /* Create and initialize MD_Symbol_Table.
00261  * Creates a hash table of initial size 2 * expected_size rounded up
00262  * to the closest power of two.  (Min hash size 32)
00263  */
00264 static MD_Symbol_Table *
00265 MD_new_symbol_table (MD * md, char *name, int expected_size)
00266 {
00267   MD_Symbol_Table *table;
00268   MD_Symbol **hash;
00269   unsigned int min_size, hash_size;
00270   unsigned int i;
00271 
00272 
00273   /* If expected size negative, force to be 0 */
00274   if (expected_size < 0)
00275     expected_size = 0;
00276 
00277   /* To prevent infinite loop by sizing algorithm (and running out of
00278    * memory :) ), expected_size must be <= a billion.
00279    */
00280   if (expected_size > 1000000000)
00281     MD_punt (md, "MD_Symbol_Table: unreasonable expected_size (%u)",
00282              expected_size);
00283 
00284   /* Want a minumum size of at least twice the expected size */
00285   min_size = expected_size * 2;
00286 
00287   /* Start with a minumum hash size of 32.  
00288    * (Smaller sizes don't work as well with the hashing algorithm)
00289    */
00290   hash_size = 32;
00291 
00292   /* Double hash_size until min_size is reached or exceeded */
00293   while (hash_size < min_size)
00294     hash_size = hash_size << 1;
00295 
00296 
00297   /* Sanity check (debugging purposes) */
00298   if (MD_Symbol_Table_pool == NULL)
00299     {
00300       MD_punt (NULL, "MD routines not initialized (call MD_new_md() first)!");
00301 
00302     }
00303 
00304   /* Allocate symbol table */
00305   table = (MD_Symbol_Table *) L_alloc (MD_Symbol_Table_pool);
00306 
00307   /* Allocate array for hash */
00308   hash = (MD_Symbol **) malloc (hash_size * sizeof (MD_Symbol *));
00309   if (hash == NULL)
00310     {
00311       MD_punt (md, "MD_new_symbol_table: Out of memory, hash array size %i.",
00312                hash_size);
00313     }
00314 
00315   /* Initialize hash table */
00316   for (i = 0; i < (int) hash_size; i++)
00317     hash[i] = NULL;
00318 
00319   /* Initialize fields */
00320   table->md = md;
00321   table->name = MD_strdup (name);
00322   table->hash = hash;
00323   table->hash_size = hash_size;
00324   table->hash_mask = hash_size - 1;   /* AND mask, works only for power of 2 */
00325   /* Resize when count at 75% of hash_size */
00326   table->resize_size = hash_size - (hash_size >> 2);
00327   table->head_symbol = NULL;
00328   table->tail_symbol = NULL;
00329   table->symbol_count = 0;
00330 
00331   return (table);
00332 }
00333 
00334 /* Frees the symbol table, and optionally frees the data pointed to */
00335 void
00336 MD_delete_symbol_table (MD_Symbol_Table * table,
00337                         void (*free_routine) (void *))
00338 {
00339   MD_Symbol *symbol, *next_symbol;
00340 
00341   /* For all the symbols in the table, free each one */
00342   for (symbol = table->head_symbol; symbol != NULL; symbol = next_symbol)
00343     {
00344       /* Get the next symbol before deleting this one */
00345       next_symbol = symbol->next_symbol;
00346 
00347       /* If free routine specified, free data */
00348       if (free_routine != NULL)
00349         free_routine (symbol->data);
00350 
00351       /* Free symbol structure */
00352       L_free (MD_Symbol_pool, symbol);
00353     }
00354 
00355   /* Free the hash array and table name */
00356   free (table->hash);
00357   free (table->name);
00358 
00359   /* Free the table structure */
00360   L_free (MD_Symbol_Table_pool, table);
00361 }
00362 
00363 /* Doubles the symbol table hash array size */
00364 static void
00365 MD_resize_symbol_table (MD_Symbol_Table * table)
00366 {
00367   MD_Symbol **new_hash, *symbol, *hash_head;
00368   int new_hash_size;
00369   unsigned int new_hash_mask, new_hash_index;
00370   int i;
00371 
00372   /* Double the size of the hash array */
00373   new_hash_size = table->hash_size * 2;
00374 
00375   /* Allocate new hash array */
00376   new_hash = (MD_Symbol **) malloc (new_hash_size * sizeof (MD_Symbol *));
00377   if (new_hash == NULL)
00378     {
00379       MD_punt (table->md,
00380                "MD_resize_symbol_table: Out of memory, new size %i.",
00381                new_hash_size);
00382     }
00383 
00384   /* Initialize new hash table */
00385   for (i = 0; i < new_hash_size; i++)
00386     new_hash[i] = NULL;
00387 
00388   /* Get the hash mask for the new hash table */
00389   new_hash_mask = new_hash_size - 1;  /* AND mask, works only for power of 2 */
00390 
00391   /* Go though all the symbol and add to new hash table.
00392    * Can totally disreguard old hash links.
00393    */
00394   for (symbol = table->head_symbol; symbol != NULL;
00395        symbol = symbol->next_symbol)
00396     {
00397       /* Get index into hash table to use for this name */
00398       new_hash_index = symbol->hash_val & new_hash_mask;
00399 
00400       /* Add symbol to head of linked list */
00401       hash_head = new_hash[new_hash_index];
00402       symbol->next_hash = hash_head;
00403       symbol->prev_hash = NULL;
00404       if (hash_head != NULL)
00405         hash_head->prev_hash = symbol;
00406       new_hash[new_hash_index] = symbol;
00407     }
00408 
00409   /* Free old hash table */
00410   free (table->hash);
00411 
00412   /* Initialize table fields for new hash table */
00413   table->hash = new_hash;
00414   table->hash_size = new_hash_size;
00415   table->hash_mask = new_hash_mask;
00416   /* Resize when count at 75% of new_hash_size */
00417   table->resize_size = new_hash_size - (new_hash_size >> 2);
00418 }
00419 
00420 /* Hashes a string, returning an unsigned 32 bit number. */
00421 static unsigned int
00422 MD_hash_string (char *string)
00423 {
00424   unsigned int hash_val;
00425   unsigned char *ptr;
00426   unsigned int ch;
00427 
00428   hash_val = 0;
00429 
00430   /* Scan through all the characters, adding the characters to the
00431    * hash value.  Multiply the hash value by 17 (using shifts) before
00432    * adding each character in.
00433    * 
00434    * This very quick hash algorithm was tuned to work well with
00435    * strings ending with numbers.
00436    */
00437   ptr = (unsigned char *) string;
00438   while ((ch = *ptr) != 0)
00439     {
00440       /* Multiply hash_val by 17 by adding 16*hash_val to it.
00441        * (Use a shift, integer multiply is usually very expensive)
00442        */
00443       hash_val += (hash_val << 4);
00444 
00445       /* Add in character value */
00446       hash_val += ch;
00447 
00448       /* Goto next character */
00449       ptr++;
00450     }
00451 
00452   /* Return the hash value */
00453   return (hash_val);
00454 }
00455 
00456 /* Adds MD structure to symbol table, name and data are not copied!!! 
00457  * Dynamically increases symbol table's hash array.
00458  * Returns pointer to added symbol.
00459  */
00460 static MD_Symbol *
00461 MD_add_symbol (MD_Symbol_Table * table, char *name, void *data)
00462 {
00463   MD_Symbol *symbol, *hash_head, *check_symbol, *tail_symbol;
00464   unsigned int hash_val, hash_index;
00465   int symbol_count;
00466 
00467   /* Increase symbol table size if necessary before adding new symbol.  
00468    * This will change the hash_mask if the table is resized!
00469    */
00470   symbol_count = table->symbol_count;
00471   if (symbol_count >= table->resize_size)
00472     {
00473       MD_resize_symbol_table (table);
00474     }
00475 
00476   /* Allocate a symbol (pool initialized in create table routine) */
00477   symbol = (MD_Symbol *) L_alloc (MD_Symbol_pool);
00478 
00479   /* Initialize fields */
00480   symbol->name = name;
00481   symbol->data = data;
00482   symbol->table = table;
00483   symbol->symbol_id = -1;       /* Used by MD_write_md only */
00484 
00485   /* Get tail symbol for ease of use */
00486   tail_symbol = table->tail_symbol;
00487 
00488   /* Add to linked list of symbols */
00489   symbol->next_symbol = NULL;
00490   symbol->prev_symbol = tail_symbol;
00491 
00492   if (tail_symbol == NULL)
00493     table->head_symbol = symbol;
00494   else
00495     tail_symbol->next_symbol = symbol;
00496   table->tail_symbol = symbol;
00497 
00498   /* Get hash value of name and put in symbol structure for quick compare
00499    * and table resize.
00500    */
00501   hash_val = MD_hash_string (name);
00502   symbol->hash_val = hash_val;
00503 
00504   /* Get index into hash table to use for this name */
00505   hash_index = hash_val & table->hash_mask;
00506 
00507   /* Get head symbol in current linked list for ease of use */
00508   hash_head = table->hash[hash_index];
00509 
00510 
00511   /* Sanity check (may want to ifdef out later).
00512 
00513    * Check that this symbol's name is not already in the symbol table.
00514    * Punt if it is, since can cause a major debugging nightmare.
00515    */
00516   for (check_symbol = hash_head; check_symbol != NULL;
00517        check_symbol = check_symbol->next_hash)
00518     {
00519       /* Check hash value before doing strcmp to avoid function
00520        * call when possible.
00521        */
00522       if ((check_symbol->hash_val == hash_val) &&
00523           (strcmp (check_symbol->name, name) == 0))
00524         {
00525           MD_punt (table->md,
00526                    "%s: cannot add '%s', already in table!", table->name,
00527                    name);
00528         }
00529     }
00530 
00531 
00532   /* Add symbol to head of linked list */
00533   symbol->next_hash = hash_head;
00534   symbol->prev_hash = NULL;
00535   if (hash_head != NULL)
00536     hash_head->prev_hash = symbol;
00537   table->hash[hash_index] = symbol;
00538 
00539   /* Update table's symbol count */
00540   table->symbol_count = symbol_count + 1;
00541 
00542   /* Return symbol added */
00543   return (symbol);
00544 }
00545 
00546 /* Renames a symbol (name is still not copied and old name is not freed!)
00547  * Punts if new name is already in symbol table.
00548  */
00549 static void
00550 MD_rename_symbol (MD_Symbol * symbol, char *new_name)
00551 {
00552   MD_Symbol_Table *table;
00553   MD_Symbol *hash_head, *check_symbol;
00554   unsigned int hash_val, hash_index;
00555 
00556   /* Get symbol table for ease of use */
00557   table = symbol->table;
00558 
00559 
00560   /* Get index into hash table for old name */
00561   hash_index = symbol->hash_val & table->hash_mask;
00562 
00563   /* Remove symbol hash linked list */
00564   if (symbol->prev_hash == NULL)
00565     table->hash[hash_index] = symbol->next_hash;
00566   else
00567     symbol->prev_hash->next_hash = symbol->next_hash;
00568 
00569   if (symbol->next_hash != NULL)
00570     symbol->next_hash->prev_hash = symbol->prev_hash;
00571 
00572 
00573   /* Get hash value of new name and put in symbol structure for quick compare
00574    * and table resize.
00575    */
00576   symbol->name = new_name;
00577   hash_val = MD_hash_string (new_name);
00578   symbol->hash_val = hash_val;
00579 
00580   /* Get index into hash table to use for this name */
00581   hash_index = hash_val & table->hash_mask;
00582 
00583   /* Get head symbol in current linked list for ease of use */
00584   hash_head = table->hash[hash_index];
00585 
00586   /* 
00587    * Check that this symbol's name is not already in the symbol table.
00588    * Punt if it is, since can cause a major debugging nightmare.
00589    */
00590   for (check_symbol = hash_head; check_symbol != NULL;
00591        check_symbol = check_symbol->next_hash)
00592     {
00593       /* Check hash value before doing strcmp to avoid function
00594        * call when possible.
00595        */
00596       if ((check_symbol->hash_val == hash_val) &&
00597           (strcmp (check_symbol->name, new_name) == 0))
00598         {
00599           MD_punt (table->md,
00600                    "%s: cannot rename to '%s', already in table!",
00601                    table->name, new_name);
00602         }
00603     }
00604 
00605 
00606   /* Add symbol to head of linked list */
00607   symbol->next_hash = hash_head;
00608   symbol->prev_hash = NULL;
00609   if (hash_head != NULL)
00610     hash_head->prev_hash = symbol;
00611   table->hash[hash_index] = symbol;
00612 }
